section.title: Organizing the World of Games

li.p: You will learn that games can be organized into many different groups based on how the games are played.
You will learn the difference between games of perfect and imperfect information.
You will learn the difference between symmetric and asymmetric games.
You will learn how to play Nim.

section.observation: What types of genres of games do you enjoy? What do you enjoy about them?
section.p: One of the major goals of mathematical thinking is the ability to organize objects into groups based on their properties. The first layer of this is determine whether something is a game. But once we have a game, there are many additional ways to continue to try to categorize it.

One of the first ways you might think of organizing a game is based on the number of players. Chess is a game played by two players. Board games commonly accommodate two to four players. And a game like Sudoku is a single player game.

We can also consider whether a game includes an element of chance or does not. Chance is introduced into a game any time there is some type of randomizing element. This can be in the form of rolling dice, spinning a wheel, or drawing cards. In some contexts, it can be helpful to imagine that chance is just another player in the game. For example, instead of rolling a die, you can imagine that the player "chance" is simply selecting a number from 1 to 6. But for our purposes, we will hold the view that is part of the game and not a player.

Another property of a game is whether the there is information that is hidden from some or all of the players. For example, one of the reasons poker is interesting is because the each player has their own cards that nobody else can see, and one of the challenges is to try to figure out what cards the other players might be holding based on how they are behaving. In a game like Monopoly, there is a stack of cards (Chance or Community Chest) and the players aren't allowed to peek at them in advance. This means that when a player lands on one of those positions, information that was hidden becomes revealed to all of the players. Another way that information can be hidden is when there is an element of chance. An outcome may depend on which number is rolled, and none of the players have access to that information. The opposite of this is a gmae where all the information is in front of the players from the very beginning. The games of chess and checker are examples of this. There is no part of the game that his hidden from the players. We have special terms for these game types.

definition.title: Games with Perfect and Imperfect Information

statement.p: A game with perfect information is a game in which all the players have access to all of the information in a game. A game with imperfect information is a game in which at least one of the players does not have access to all of the information in a game. This includes players not knowing the outcome of future chance events. Some people use the terms complete and incomplete information instead of perfect and imperfect information, respectively.

section.p: Most people are familiar with games in each of the above categories, as the typical types of games that people play include games on both sides of the line for each of the divisions. But there are still more ways to categorize games. These categories are generally intuitive to understand, but it may be harder to think of examples.

Games can be either competitive or cooperative. A cooperative game is one where all of the players win or lose as a single team. There are plenty of examples of these types of games, but they are likely less familiar to the average person. Instead, most people are able to think of competitive games. These are games where, at the end of the game, some players win and some players lose. It's important to note that competitive games may involve some elements of cooperation, where you might develop temporary alliances because you can attain some sort of benefit from it.

A more abstract way of looking at games is to consider the possible moves for each player. In some games, each player has their own pieces that they control, and so each player has a different set of possible moves at any given moment in the game. But there are some games in which all players have the exact same possible decisions all the time. We will start with the formal definition.

statement.p: A symmetric game is a game for which both players have identical options at any decision point during the game. An asymmetric game is a game where one player has an option available to them that the other player (or players) do not.

section.p: Any game where each player has their own pieces to move is an asymmetric game. For example, chess is an asymmetric game. The word "identical" in this definition is a key point to focus on. Even though chess starts off with the pieces in a mirror image of each other, and both players move their corresponding pieces in the same way, that's not what is meant by identical. When it's white's turn, they can move a white pawn in a certain way. But if it were black's turn, they would not be able to move that same white pawn in the same way. They are forbidden from moving any of white's pieces at all! So when you think about identical moves, you want to think of it as literally being able to do the exact same thing in the exact same way.

A symmetric game that you might know is called "Nim." This is an example of a heap game, which is just a general term for games that are played with tokens that are put into piles (heaps), and the gmae is played by manipulating those heaps. These games are convenient because they can be played with objects that are just lying around. Examples of convenient tokens are coins, beans, or small stones. We will explain the rules of the game and then discuss why it's a symmetric game.

statement.p: Nim is two-player heap game. Players take turns selecting a heap and removing any number of tokens from it. The player who takes the last token from the last remaining heap is the winner.

A common starting arrangement is to have one heap of size three, one heap of size five, and one heap of size seven. However, the game can start with any number of heaps with any number of tokens in them.

section.p: This is a symmetric game because both players have access to the exact same moves from any position. There is no sense in which one player has their own heaps that the other player can't take from. All the heaps are neutral and when it's each player's turn they have the same rules for how they can make their next move.
We will close this section by introducting a useful concept for talking about games.

statement.p: At any instant for any game, the game state is the collection of all of the information necessary to describe the current game decision point.

section.p: For Nim, the game state is the list of all of the heaps with the number of tokens in each heap. We do not need to know whose turn it is because the game is symmetric. The available decisions for either player is the same. For checkers, the game state is the position of every checker on the board and which color is next to move. We need to know whose turn it is because that tells us which pieces are available to be moved.

Thinking about game states will be useful for us as we start to analyze games. It's important to note that the game state does not necessarily contain the information about how you got to that point. For example, the game state for Nim might be that there is only one heap with three tokens in it. We have no idea what combination of moves actually got us to this position. It turns out that (at least for this game) how you got to a position is irrelevant for how you strategize moving forward.

exercisegroup.title: Identifying Features of Games
exercisegroup.p:
For each of the following games, identify the following features:
The number of players (it may be a range of numbers)
Whether it is a game with or without chance
Whether it is a game with complete or incomplete information
Whether it is a cooperative or competitive game
Whether it is a symmetric or asymmetric game

exercisegroup.title: Exploring Nim
exercisegroup.p: Later in the course, we are going to learn some formal techniques for analyzing games. But for now, we will simply use intuition and experience to analyze the game (tools that everyone has access to).

exercise.p: Suppose that it's your turn, and there is only one heap with four tokens in it. What is your best play and why? Can you generalize from this situation and come up with a strategy for similar sitations?

Suppose that it's your turn, and there are two heaps remaining. One heap has 4 tokens and the other heap has just 1 token. What is your play and why? Can you generalize from this situation and come up with a strategy for similar situations?
